instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.P3V3S5_EN_L: What is P3V3S5_EN_L? P3V3S5_EN_L is a signal that enables the power chip responsible for creating PP3V3_S5 when it is low. .
definitions.P5VS3_EN_L: What is P5VS3_EN_L? P5VS3_EN_L is a signal that enables the PP5V_S3 power rail when it is low.  _L means whatever before the _L in the signal name is asserted when it is low voltage, such as 0.0v to 0.5v..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> @2.0V
threads.message:
Im having trouble with this board on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>, when I inject voltage <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> gets hot, I already replaced <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> with no change.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 12.60
PP3V42 = 3.42V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> = 4.9V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> = 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> = 3.29V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> = 2.0V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> = 0v
<SIGNAL>P5VS3_EN_L</SIGNAL> = 0v (pulses 3.3V when I turn on the PSU, then drops)
<SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN_L</SIGNAL> = 0v (pulses 3.3V when I turn on the PSU, then drops) 
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> = 3.3V

<CHIP>U7941</CHIP>
PIN 1 = 3,42
PIN 2 = 3,42
 PIN 3 = 3,42
PIN 4 = 0V
PIN 5 = GND
PIN 6 = 3,3
PIN 7 = 0V
PIN 8 = 3,46

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> @2.0V
threads.message: Did you replace <TRANSISTOR>Q7260</TRANSISTOR> & <TRANSISTOR>Q7261</TRANSISTOR> when you swapped <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> @2.0V
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> @2.0V
threads.message: swap out the FETS, report back...swap out <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> same time from another donor.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> @2.0V
threads.message:
Just did that, still not getting <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> ... but now it is 0v instead of 2.0v which is maybe a good sign?

<SIGNAL>P5VS3_EN_L</SIGNAL> = 0v (pulses 3.3V when I turn on the PSU, then drops, when I turn off the PSU it goes high again and drops...)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> @2.0V
threads.message:
do you get any pulses on L7260 now that you have changed the FETS ? I wouldn't have expected you now have 0V there now?

Diode mode reading on L7260 ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> @2.0V
threads.message:
Post diode mode to ground at L7260.
Allow 10s after power is removed; before measuring in diode mode.

"<SIGNAL>P5VS3_EN_L</SIGNAL>"
Ends with "_L" for some reason; 0V is correct value.

Post voltage for pin 1 of <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>.
Check/replace R/<CAPACITOR>C7260</CAPACITOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> @2.0V
threads.message:
L7260 = .247 

"<SIGNAL>P5VS3_EN_L</SIGNAL>"
Ends with "_L" for some reason; 0V is correct value.  ----> So on the entrip1 and entrip2 of <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> I will get 0V correct?

PIN 1 <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> = 0V
Replaced R/<CAPACITOR>C7260</CAPACITOR>, still not getting further...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> @2.0V
threads.message:
"So on the entrip1 and entrip2 of <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> I will get 0V correct?"
Why 0V?
Read datasheet.

Looks like bad <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>; pin 1 should have 1.15V.
Remove <TRANSISTOR>Q7221</TRANSISTOR> first, just in case.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> @2.0V
threads.message:
Replaced <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>
PIN 1 = 1.22v
replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q7221</TRANSISTOR>, still getting 2v at <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> @2.0V
threads.message:
Pin 1 is good now.
Replace <TRANSISTOR>Q7260</TRANSISTOR>/61 and R/<CAPACITOR>C7260</CAPACITOR>.
Be sure all traces/solders and surrounding components are good.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> @2.0V
threads.message:
Still the same, I replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q7260</TRANSISTOR>/61 and R/<CAPACITOR>C7260</CAPACITOR> still getting 2v at <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>
 is it worth removing <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> and injecting voltage on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> line?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> @2.0V
threads.message:
Why, if there is no short???

Check <RESISTOR>R7267</RESISTOR>/68 values.
Play with RA/RB untill get correct output voltage.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> @2.0V
threads.message: CHANGED <RESISTOR>R7267</RESISTOR>/68 and now it is working apparently fine... thank you!!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> @2.0V
threads.message: So this board turned on fine, but I am having a trouble with the Audio, the icon is there, I can adjust the volume up and down, but I canÂ´t get any sound come out of the speakers... no even using headphones... IÂ´ve checked <CHIP>U6200</CHIP>/01 so far and everything seems to be ok... what can cause that?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> @2.0V
threads.message:
Any red light visible inside audio connector?
Try removing <RESISTOR>R6805</RESISTOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> @2.0V
threads.message:
Hi, no red light on the audio jack, the volume bar works, the output says: "internal speakers" but I get no audio out from the speakers. 
I connected some headphones in the jack and the output is still in "internal speakers" and doesnÂ´t change to headphones like it usually does...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> @2.0V
threads.message:
Looks like there is a problem with audio connector, if remains stuck on internal speakers.
Check all traces, small coils and resistors in series with the connector.
Also check <CHIP>U6200</CHIP> output voltage.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> @2.0V
threads.message: changed <CHIP>U6610</CHIP>/20 and now sound is working fine... thank you!
